nodes.text: State-level economic policy uncertainty can be measured using local newspaper text and these state-level EPU measures capture meaningful variation that helps explain and foreshadow state economic performance
We construct three monthly state-level EPU indexes per state: EPU-S (state and local sources), EPU-N (national and international sources), and EPU-C (composite)

Method: Using digital archives for about 3,500 local newspapers we flag articles that contain terms for economy, uncertainty, and either state-policy or national-policy term sets, compute raw ratios of flagged articles to total articles by state-month, and normalize to yield index values

Context and assumption: Newspapers are used because they are frequent, historically deep, topical, allow subnational coverage, and averaging across many papers reduces idiosyncratic noise; we assume coverage reflects local policy uncertainty

Claim: State and local matters are major sources of measured state-level policy uncertainty; before COVID about 50% of composite EPU articles discussed national matters, 30% state/local, 20% both, and after March 2020 the share discussing state/local rose substantially

Result: The predominant source of state-level policy uncertainty shifted toward state and local sources after the COVID-19 pandemic, with cross-state average EPU-S to EPU-N ratio rising from 0.65 pre-pandemic to 1.1 from March 2020 to June 2021

Claim and evidence: Elections raise EPU; close presidential elections raise EPU-N by about 60 percent and close gubernatorial elections raise EPU-S by about 35 percent, controlling for state conditions and seasonality
Claim and evidence: Selected national and international events (9-11, debt-ceiling crisis, Brexit, Trump 2016, government shutdowns) produced large, heterogeneous spikes in EPU-N across most states

Result: State-level EPU series display both common and substantial idiosyncratic variation across states and over time; first principal component explains more of EPU-N than EPU-S variation, and average pairwise correlations are modest except around major events

Claim and method: In panel VARs fit to pre-COVID monthly data we identify policy uncertainty shocks and find upward own-state ln(EPU-C) shocks foreshadow higher unemployment, lower employment, and weaker housing outcomes, peaking about one year later

Result and evidence: Preferred panel VAR estimates imply a unit standard deviation ln(EPU-C) shock raises unemployment with a peak of about 0.10 percentage points after roughly 11-14 months; effects are modest but statistically precise and larger for bigger states

Claim and evidence: Policy uncertainty shocks spill across borders: upward EPU shocks in bordering states negatively affect own-state economic activity and own-state and border-state shocks of equal size have similar unemployment impacts

Pandemic-specific findings: COVID-19 produced huge increases in both EPU-N and EPU-S; across states the increase in policy uncertainty is strongly associated with lockdown stringency (shelter-in-place, business, restaurant, school closure orders) but not with COVID deaths per capita; states with stricter lockdowns experienced larger unemployment increases and higher EPU

Illustrative case: California experienced large state-specific EPU-S spikes during the 2000-01 electricity crisis and the subsequent political turmoil; historical VAR decomposition implies realized EPU shocks can account for sizable swings in state unemployment (up to about two percentage points)

Conclusion and limitation: State-level newspaper-based EPU indexes are valuable tools for research on subnational policy uncertainty and economic outcomes, but results are subject to caveats including measurement noise in small-state series, potential confounders in pandemic regressions, and the usual limits of VAR identification
